text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Vendors of toy balloons, at
First Avenue and 114th Street. The view is north.
The woman is wearing a "Helen Wills" eyeshade; these were very
much in fashion the preceding year.
July 16, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A man and his son buying votive candles. Notice that refreshments
are also for sale here.
July 16, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Booths displaying souvenirs, food, etc., on First Avenue, east side, at 114th Street and Jefferson Park.
July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Broiled meat at the Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, at an out-door booth, First Avenue, east side, Jefferson Park.
July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Cheese vendor with truck, 114th Street, north side, between First and Pleasant Avenues.
July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

text:
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Parade, marching south on First Avenue past the filling station adjoining the S.W. corner of 109th Street. A woman in the center of the picture is carrying wax votive images of a head and an abdomen. These will be carried into the church and laid at Our Lady's altar. The filling station in the background was built since 1925, replacing three old frame sheds. The angle made by the building on the left is due to the property line, which at this point coincided with the S.W. side of Roosevelt Road, a country road long since obliterated. July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Parade, entering and turning south on First Avenue at 115th Street. Jefferson Park lies on the east side of First Avenue from 114th to 111th Streets. July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Parade, moving east on 114th Street opposite N.W. corner of First Avenue. The girl in the foreground is carrying a giant candle on her head. July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

text:
(1) Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Parade going west on 114th Street past Jefferson Park, east of First Avenue, showing the banner of the Little Brothers of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, a religious society, with offerings of paper currency pinned to it.

July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Parade, entering First Avenue from 105th Street (the view is west), showing two elaborate candelabra, borne by women on their heads.

July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Parade, in an unidentified street, showing candelabra in same detail.

July 16, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, No. 10-12.

text:
2224 First Avenue, adjoining N. E. corner of 114th Street. This house will stand in 1934.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

346 East 114th Street, south side, west of First Avenue. This is a one-story frame shack at the south end of a vacant lot, left by demolition of a three-story frame house. In the background is a three-story frame house at the rear of 343 East 113th
Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York,

Jefferson Park: A view showing children wading in a shallow pool on the north side of the Park that lies east of First Ave. The photographer is viewing north-westward to show buildings on East 114th Street. The 5 story structure with a cross mounted atop same is given as a M.E. Church (no name) by Bromley's Atlas of 1922. It is in this vicinity that the street carnivals for the Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel are held; the Church being around the corner on East 115th Street.

July 1933.

George L. Balgue.

A photograph showing the bandstand that is located in the easterly portion of the Park. Subsequently the East River Drive will be constructed at the left.

July 1933

George L. Balgue

July 1933

Clams on a pushcart on Pleasant Avenue, at the N.W. corner of 114th Street.

text:
(1) Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: A pedlar with rubber toys, on the S.E. corner of First Avenue and 114th Street; the view is north.

July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Refreshments on the Feast Day of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: corn on the cob and soda pop for sale.
The scene is First Avenue near 114th Street.
July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another ear of corn, on 114th Street east of Pleasant Avenue.
The old Standard Gas-Light works on the north side of the street, which now belong to Consolidated Gas, are about to be demolished.

July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

folder: 114th Street Between 1st and Pleasant Avenues, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: A travelling ice cream vendor taking in some business at Jefferson Park opposite 401-409 East 114th Street, east of First Avenue. This truck makes a trip of 15,000 miles, through twenty-seven different states, taking in such festivals as the Mardi Gras at New Orleans, Louisiana, and the Apple Carnival at Portland, Oregon. Notice the sign on the wall of 401 East 114th Street.
July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Vendor of rosaries, buttons, and souvenirs, also a fruit and nut pushcart, in Pleasant Avenue, north of the intersection of 115th Street. The east side of the Avenue, to 116th Street, is shown.
July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A watermelon stand at the northwest entrance to Jefferson Park, 114th Street at S.W. corner of First Avenue; the view is northeast, showing the north side of 114th Street.
July 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, 1935, No. 9: The parade, pass-ing the gas tank on the west side of First Avenue, 110th to 111th Streets.

July 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.

text:
Jefferson Park: Three views in a southwestward direction progressively from East 114th Street, showing the new swimming pool and hand-ball courts.

Buildings and gas holders in the background are on the west side of First Avenue, at East111th Street. The park is on the east side of the Avenue and extends from 111th to 114th Streets.

1938
Views: 1-2-3

Gift of Committee on Housing
Charity Organization Society

Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel-1939: Refreshment stands at the N. W. corner of First Avenue and East 114th Street.

No. 3 shows the street procession on one of the neighboring
side streets.

July 16, 1939
No's. 10-11-12

P. L. Sperr
